review.title: Removing systematic errors for exoplanet search via latent causes
review.abstract: We describe a method for removing the effect of confounders in order to reconstruct a latent quantity of interest. The method, referred to as half-sibling regression, is inspired by recent work in causal inference using additive noise models. We provide a theoretical justification and illustrate the potential of the method in a challenging astronomy application.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: We have studied semi-sibling regression, a simple but effective method for eliminating the effect of systematic noise from observations. It uses the information contained in a number of other observations influenced by the same sound source. The main motivation for the method was its application to the data processing of exoplanets, which we have discussed in detail, with quite promising results. However, we expect that it will also have a wide range of applications in other areas. We expect that our method could enable astronomical discoveries with higher sensitivity to existing Kepler satellite data. Furthermore, we expect that methods for eliminating systematic errors will become more important: by May 2013, two of the four reaction wheels used to control the Kepler spacecraft will be dysfunctional, and in May 2014 NASA announced the K2 mission, with the remaining two wheels combined with the rudders to control the remaining spacecraft's two spacecraft wheels to control the search for the exoplanet and the other two spacecraft will be used significantly in the search for exoplanets.
